sourceText: Republic (Allegory of the Cave, Book VII; Myth of Er, Book X); Timaeus
note: Three Platonic cosmological models compared level by level. The Cave allegory describes the ascent from illusion to truth in three stages. The Myth of Er maps the soul's postmortem journey through the planetary spheres. The Timaeus describes the Demiurge's construction of the cosmos. Not all levels appear in all three works.

Material World.cave: Prisoners bound in the cave, seeing only shadows on the wall
Material World.mythOfEr: The material world — death on the battlefield, the meadow of judgment
Material World.timaeus: Body, material — the receptacle (Chora), the realm of becoming

Turning / Axis.cave: The turning — unshackling, first glimpse of the fire casting the shadows
Turning / Axis.mythOfEr: The rainbow and the spindle of Necessity — the axis of the cosmos

Moon.timaeus: Moon — first circle of the mixture

Sun.cave: Ascent into daylight — seeing reflected images, then the Sun itself
Sun.timaeus: Sun — center of the planetary circles

Fixed Stars.timaeus: Fixed stars — the circle of the Same

World Soul.mythOfEr: The World Soul — Anima Mundi, the living cosmos
World Soul.timaeus: World Soul — the rational living creature that enfolds all

Forms / Nous.cave: The Form of the Good — the Sun as metaphor, the source of all truth and illumination
Forms / Nous.mythOfEr: Ideas, Forms, Nous — the archetypal realm beyond the spheres
Forms / Nous.timaeus: Forms, Ideas, the Demiurge — the rational principle, the craftsman god

The One / The Good.mythOfEr: The One — the Good, Love, Beauty, Harmony
The One / The Good.timaeus: The undivided source — beyond being, the ground of all reality
